12.text: When we use the word "architect" or "designer,"

16.text: what we usually mean is a professional,

21.text: and we tend to assume that it's those professionals

24.text: who are going to be the ones to help us solve

26.text: the really big, systemic design challenges that we face

28.text: like climate change, urbanization and social inequality.

32.text: That's our kind of working presumption.

35.text: And I think it's wrong, actually.

38.text: In 2008, I was just about to graduate from architecture school

41.text: after several years, and go out and get a job,

47.text: The economy ran out of jobs.

49.text: And a couple of things struck me about this.

52.text: One, don't listen to career advisers.

56.text: And two, actually this is a fascinating paradox for architecture,

60.text: which is that, as a society, we've never needed design thinking more,

64.text: and yet architecture was literally becoming unemployed.

68.text: It strikes me that we talk very deeply about design,

72.text: but actually there's an economics behind architecture

74.text: that we don't talk about, and I think we need to.

77.text: And a good place to start is your own paycheck.

80.text: So, as a bottom-of-the-rung architecture graduate,

83.text: I might expect to earn about 24,000 pounds.

89.text: Now in terms of the whole world's population,

91.text: that already puts me in the top 1.95 richest people,

102.text: actually almost everything that we call architecture today

107.text: for about the richest one percent of the world's population,

113.text: The reason why we forgot that

114.text: is because the times in history when architecture

116.text: did the most to transform society were those times

119.text: when, actually, the one percent would build

122.text: on behalf of the 99 percent, for various different reasons,

125.text: whether that was through philanthropy in the 19th century,

130.text: the welfare state, and most recently, of course,

133.text: through this inflated real estate bubble.

137.text: And all of those booms, in their own various ways,

142.text: and we're back in this situation

144.text: where the smartest designers and architects in the world

149.text: are only really able to work for one percent of the population.

153.text: Now it's not just that that's bad for democracy,

155.text: though I think it probably is,

157.text: it's actually not a very clever business strategy, actually.

160.text: I think the challenge facing the next generation of architects

163.text: is, how are we going to turn our client

165.text: from the one percent to the 100 percent?

168.text: And I want to offer three slightly counterintuitive ideas

172.text: for how it might be done.

174.text: The first is, I think we need to question this idea

177.text: that architecture is about making buildings.

179.text: Actually, a building is about the most expensive solution

182.text: you can think of to almost any given problem.

185.text: And fundamentally, design should be much, much more interested

188.text: in solving problems and creating new conditions.

192.text: The office was working with a school,

194.text: and they had an old Victorian school building.

196.text: And they said to the architects, "Look,

199.text: our corridors are an absolute nightmare.

201.text: They're far too small. They get congested between classes.

203.text: There's bullying. We can't control them.

205.text: So what we want you to do is re-plan our entire building,

208.text: and we know it's going to cost several million pounds,

210.text: but we're reconciled to the fact."

212.text: And the team thought about this, and they went away,

215.text: and they said, "Actually, don't do that.

217.text: Instead, get rid of the school bell.

220.text: And instead of having one school bell that goes off once,

223.text: have several smaller school bells that go off

225.text: in different places and different times,

227.text: distribute the traffic through the corridors."

231.text: but instead of spending several million pounds,

236.text: Now, it looks like you're doing yourself out of a job,

239.text: but you're not. You're actually making yourself more useful.

241.text: Architects are actually really, really good

243.text: at this kind of resourceful, strategic thinking.

245.text: And the problem is that, like a lot of design professions,

247.text: we got fixated on the idea of providing

249.text: a particular kind of consumer product,

251.text: and I don't think that needs to be the case anymore.

254.text: The second idea worth questioning is this 20th-century thing

258.text: that mass architecture is about big --

264.text: Actually, we've got ourselves locked into this

266.text: Industrial Era mindset which says that

268.text: the only people who can make cities are large organizations

272.text: or corporations who build on our behalf,

276.text: in single, monolithic projects, and of course,

282.text: So what you end up with are single, monolithic neighborhoods

285.text: based on this kind of one-size-fits-all model.

289.text: And a lot of people can't even afford them.

291.text: But what if, actually, it's possible now for cities

294.text: to be made not just by the few with a lot

297.text: but also by the many with a bit?

300.text: And when they do, they bring with them

301.text: a completely different set of values about the place that they want to live.

305.text: And it raises really interesting questions about,

307.text: how will we plan cities? How will finance development?

310.text: How will we sell design services?

312.text: What would it mean for democratic societies

314.text: to offer their citizens a right to build?

316.text: And in a way it should be kind of obvious, right,

319.text: that in the 21st century, maybe cities can be developed by citizens.

324.text: And thirdly, we need to remember that,

327.text: from a strictly economic point of view,

330.text: design shares a category with sex and care of the elderly --

339.text: Most of the work takes place outside of the monetary economy

342.text: in what's called the social economy or the core economy,

345.text: which is people doing it for themselves.

347.text: And the problem is that, up until now,

350.text: it was the monetary economy which had

352.text: all the infrastructure and all the tools.

439.text: So about a year and a half ago,

441.text: we started working on a project called WikiHouse,

443.text: and WikiHouse is an open-source construction system.

446.text: And the idea is to make it possible for anyone

449.text: to go online, access a freely shared library

451.text: of 3D models which they can download and adapt in,

456.text: at the moment, SketchUp, because it's free, and it's easy to use,

459.text: and almost at the click of a switch

462.text: they can generate a set of cutting files

466.text: to print out the parts from a house using a CNC machine

470.text: and a standard sheet material like plywood.

473.text: And the parts are all numbered,

476.text: and basically what you end up with is a really big IKEA kit.

482.text: And it goes together without any bolts.

485.text: It uses wedge and peg connections.

487.text: And even the mallets to make it

489.text: can be provided on the cutting sheets as well.

491.text: And a team of about two or three people,

496.text: They don't need any traditional construction skills.

519.text: onto which you can then apply systems like windows

522.text: and cladding and insulation and services

527.text: Of course, the house is never finished.

529.text: We're shifting our heads here, so the house is not a finished product.

535.text: over its life or even use it to make the house next door.

546.text: And we and others have built a few prototypes around the world now,

550.text: and some really interesting lessons here.

552.text: One of them is that it's always incredibly sociable.

554.text: People get confused between construction work and having fun.

559.text: But the principles of openness go right down

562.text: into the really mundane, physical details.

564.text: Like, never designing a piece that can't be lifted up.

567.text: Or, when you're designing a piece,

569.text: make sure you either can't put it in the wrong way round,

572.text: or, if you do, it doesn't matter, because it's symmetrical.

574.text: Probably the principal which runs deepest with us

578.text: is the principal set out by Linus Torvalds,

584.text: which was that idea of, "Be lazy like a fox."

587.text: Don't reinvent the wheel every time.

589.text: Take what already works, and adapt it for your own needs.

593.text: Contrary to almost everything that you might get taught
